description: From Middle English discomyned, discomynned, dyscomynyd (participle); equivalent to dis- +‎ common.

verbs.description: discommon (third-person singular simple present discommons, present participle discommoning, simple past and past participle discommoned)

entries.meaning: (historical, UK) To deprive of the privilege of citizenship of a town or city.
(historical, law) To deprive (lands etc.) of commonable quality, by enclosing or appropriating.
To exclude from using a commonable resource, such as land.
(transitive, UK, Oxford and Cambridge universities, historical) To deprive of the right to deal with undergraduates.
examples: […]  persons violating the above statute are liable to a fine for the first offence, and to be discommoned for the second.
